title: 103_s1683
content: The Sterling Forest and New Jersey Watershed Protection Act of 1993 allows for land acquisition. The Palisades Park Commission is authorized to acquire an open space tract of land from the Sterling Forest Corporation in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. The Commission shall manage the acquired land to enhance it. The Commission will manage the acquired land to enhance protection of watershed, outdoor recreational, wildlife habitat, and Appalachian Trail values in the Sterling Forest area of the New York/New Jersey Highlands Region. Authorization of appropriations for SEC-3. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of the Interior in the amount of $35,000,000 for acquiring land described in section 2. Transfer of funds to the Commission as necessary to carry out this Act. The "Sterling Forest Protection Act of 1994" is the short title of this Act. The findings section highlights the importance of protecting Sterling Forest. The Palisades Interstate Park Commission, established in 1937, manages 23 parks and historic sites in New York and New Jersey, totaling over 82,000 acres. With over 8 million visitors annually, the park system offers outdoor recreational opportunities. Sterling Forest, a biologically diverse open space on the New Jersey border, covers approximately 17,500 acres and serves as a significant watershed area providing clean drinking water for 25% of the state. It is also a key outdoor recreational asset in the densely populated northeastern United States region. Sterling Forest is a vital outdoor recreational area in the northeastern United States, supporting a variety of habitats and rare species. Protecting Sterling Forest would enhance the Appalachian National Scenic Trail and provide increased recreational opportunities. Protecting Sterling Forest through the Palisades Interstate Park Commission will involve minimal Federal funds due to stewardship costs being covered by New York and New Jersey. Sterling Forest offers nationally significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities. The Sterling Forest has nationally significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities, making it a cost-effective investment for permanent protection. The lack of open space in the densely populated Tri-State region highlights the clear Federal interest in acquiring Sterling Forest to protect the region's drinking water. The purpose of acquiring Sterling Forest is to protect the region's drinking water and preserve its nationally significant watershed, recreational, and wildlife qualities. The Act aims to establish the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York to protect its watershed, wildlife, and recreational resources. It authorizes federal funding for acquisition costs, directs the transfer of certain lands to the Secretary of the Interior, and provides for the management of the Reserve. The Act establishes the Sterling Forest Reserve in New York to protect its resources and authorizes federal funding for acquisition costs. It directs the transfer of certain lands to the Secretary of the Interior and assigns management to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, "Reserve" means the Sterling Forest Reserve, and "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Sterling Forest Reserve is established in New York upon the Commission's acquisition of sufficient lands. The Reserve consists of approximately 17,500 acres as depicted on the Boundary Map, available for public inspection. The Sterling Forest Reserve, established in New York in 1994, consists of approximately 17,500 acres. The Boundary Map is available for public inspection at the Commission and National Park Service offices. The Secretary will transfer funds for land acquisition, subject to specified conditions. The Commission must agree to terms before receiving federal funds. The Commission must agree to specific terms and conditions when using federal funds for land acquisition within the Sterling Forest Reserve. Failure to manage the acquired lands appropriately will result in conveying fee title to the United States. Consent of the landowner is required for any acquisition using federal funds. The Commission must acquire "National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands" and "National Park Service Conservation Easement Lands" within the Sterling Forest Reserve using Federal funds before acquiring any other lands within the Reserve, with the owner's consent required for any acquisition. The Commission must convey conservation easements on the acquired "National Park Service Wilderness Easement Lands" to the United States within 30 days. The easement lands must be managed to protect their wilderness character, while conservation easements on National Park Service lands restrict development to protect the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. The Appalachian National Scenic Trail must be protected from development and use that is not consistent with the general management plan. Funds for the Commission can only be transferred if matched by non-Federal sources. The Commission will manage lands in the Reserve according to its authorities and the Act's purposes. Within 3 years, a general management plan must be prepared and submitted for approval. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Act, with funds available until expended. A limit of $17,500,000 is set for land acquisition within the Reserve.
